campaign.story:
MALA MALA is a feature length documentary exploring the lives of young transsexuals & drag queens in Puerto Rico. Read about Mala Mala on The Huffington Post here.
NEW TRAILER! Hang out with Mala Mala at The Fair
This is our first feature length film as a directing duo, and has been an incredibly exciting experience.  We've spent the last few months filming in Puerto Rico, and with your generous support, the money we raise through Kickstarter will help us wrap filming on the island as well as assist with post production costs.  Thanks in advance for your time and support.
Transsexualism and drag defy the binary most accept as their standard, while acting as a channel to express (and inhabit) one's individuality.  Conventions are broken when men apply lashes, wigs, and dresses.  Prevailing ideas of gender are turned on their head during the transitional process of a transgendered person. And yet as "other" and both drag and transsexualism may seem to some, they both reflect the universal human need to explore and fulfill.  To live life as a trans individual is to embody a lifestyle of possibility and endless creation. 
To capture all of this--the relationship between cultural life in one of the only colonized territories still governed by the United States, and the experience of citizens who themselves inhabit deeply dualistic identities, is for us a rare opportunity to capture a beautifully unique community. 
As a trans person in Puerto Rico, not only does your experience beg the question “am I Puerto Rican, am I American, or am I both?” but also “am I a male, am I a female, or am I both?” This vagueness, this in-betweenness is what most fascinates us as filmmakers, and with this project we hope to share the stories of people who's voices may not otherwise be near enough to reach your ears.
At its core, this film is a people piece.  We are interested in the relationship between the internal and external being, the dynamics between performance and gender, and the power of self-discovery.  
We hope that you decide to become part of our community in support of our film, and reach out to us with any questions, suggestions, or any other things you'd like us to hear at DanandAntonio@gmail.com.  Thanks again.
Love,
Dan & Antonio
INTRODUCING The Boys & Girls of MALA MALA
QUEEN BEE (Carlos) All hail the queen! Carlos reigns over Puerto Rico and is adored by his fans wherever he goes. Dressed up or down he is always "Fa-bu-lous!"
APRIL (Jason) San Juan's very own sparkling diamond: 2012 is the year of April. By day, Jason makes his own costumes & serves ice cream at Maggie Moo's. By night, he's the island's It-girl. April is known to always take it to the next level and her congeniality is bowed down to wherever she goes.
KAYRA (Henry) Henry is a human rights activist on the west coast of Puerto Rico. With or without makeup, he is generous, kind, and determined; spreading the message of love and acceptance wherever he goes. Dressed up as Kayra, nothing can stop him.
ZAHARA (Alberic) The Paris Hilton of Puerto Rico, Zahara’s appearance is in constant flux. Anything to give her loving fans what they want: glamour.
ROCHELLE (Roberto) Rochelle is the intellectual of the group. When she speaks, her girls are all ears. She understands the complexity of the Puerto Rican identity and uses the best of both male and female worlds to overcome all obstacles. Her passion is acting, and if a boy is what the casting agent wants, then Rochelle has no problem morphing back into Roberto for the perfect role.
SAMANTHA Samantha is a former transsexual who began her transition with hormones from the black market until she had to stop due to medical complications. However, if the timing is right, Samantha would give the transition another try.
SOPHIA After a successful male-to-female transition in New York City, Sophia moved away to Puerto Rico to pursue her dream of owning a little bar on a small island. She ended up with Heaven & Hell, one of the biggest, and best, dance clubs in Puerto Rico.
_________________________________________________________
CAN I INCREASE MY PLEDGE ONCE IT'S BEEN MADE?
Yes! Once you donate to our campaign, you may want to change your incentive reward to a different one, or increase your pledge amount. To do so, go to Kickstarter and sign in. If you go to our campaign page, the green “Back This Project” button has been replaced with a blue “Manage Your Donation” button. Click it and you can enter a new amount, or choose a new incentive.
CAN WE EXCEED THE GOAL?
Yes! Exceeding the goal would help us pay for more of the costs to finish the film. 
IS MY PLEDGE AMOUNT PUBLICLY DISPLAYED?
No. Only you and the project owner will be able to see your pledge amount.
I'M NOT IN THE US, CAN I STILL PLEDGE?
Yes, you can pledge from anywhere.
CAN I GIFT AN INCENTIVE?
Yes! To "gift" your reward to someone else, please follow the normal process with the pledge and payment in your name. Once we've reached the deadline, we'll send you an email requesting the information we need to fulfill the reward (address, etc.) At that time, please reply with the contact info for the person that is to receive the reward and we'll follow through!
WHAT HAPPENS IF THE MONEY ISN'T RAISED IN TIME?
If our goal isn’t met before the deadline, we don't receive any of the pledges. Your credit or debit card will not be charged.
HOW CAN I CONTACT YOU?
You can send us an email through this kickstarter website OR you can contact us danandantonio@gmail.com
BUDGET
We have over 50 hours of film footage from our trips to the island. But to finish telling the MALA MALA story we need your help. With your generous contributions we will be able to fund:
Equipment Rentals (cameras, microphones, lighting, etc.)
Production Crew including Director of Photography
To continue conducting interviews, which includes air and car travel for crew.
For Editing costs (Film editing, Sound Mixing & Editing, Color Correction, Motion Graphics, Media Output).
Costs for Music Rights
Insurance
Film Festival Fees to get this story to a screen near you.

updates.update_content: Since our last update, Mala Mala has been busy. We completed our 4th (December) and 5th trip (February) to Puerto Rico. The crew got back to NYC yesterday morning and we're really happy to inform that we've completed our story shooting! Our hard drives are jampacked with funny, sad, and exciting stories and sleep-depraved adventures. Now we're getting busy editing. We've pushed back the deadline on some of the backer rewards, focusing all our resources on completing the film and delivering it to festivals on time. But don't worry, soon as we're done check your mailboxes for lots of Mala Mala goodies.
It's time...

Hi friends, family, and backers!
We're prepping for our big month-long July shoot in Puerto Rico! We're very excited. We will keep you up to date with what we encounter and discover. After receiving many kind and generous messages from people who wanted to pledge but didn't make it in time last month, we launched an Indie Gogo fundraising profile for Mala Mala. This will cover the 7% fees Amazon/Kickstarter deducted for processing the transactions and will allow us to put the movie through the best quality post-production process possible. Thank you for your support!

What an exciting day! $5 Mala Mala Happy Hour? 
Today from 6-9PM Dan Sickles will be at The Beacon Hotel in downtown DC answering questions about the documentary and screening the trailers. In support of Puerto Rican cinema, ConPRmetidos, a DC/San Juan based non-profit for the advancement of Puerto Rico's human potential, has generously offered to host this event. Please read more about their initiatives here.

campaign.story:
Hi
My name is Emmanuel Eng and I need your help to move my newest bicycle frame, the Sutro, into production. I developed the Sutro in collaboration with Mission Bicycle Company to serve as the most practical and elegant geared city bike available.
The Bike
The Sutro was designed by and for city cyclists to be ridden everyday and everywhere. We took the simplicity of a single speed bike and added the versatility of a Shimano multi-geared internal hub. Then to achieve a clean aesthetic we routed the brake and shifter cables through the frame.
Sutro with 8-speed Shimano Alfine Hub
8-Speed Internal Hub
Our first bike, the Valencia, was designed around the simplicity and dependability of single speed riding. It was our answer to the clunky, heavy and unreliable bikes marketed for the city. However, we knew one gear wasn't the solution for every rider. 
So we searched for an alternative that offered the flexibility of a fully geared bike while retaining the ease of riding and near zero maintenance we'd already developed. We fell in love with the mechanical wizardry of the Shimano internal multi-geared hubs and the potential they offered.
8-gears enclosed inside the rear hub
These hubs allow a simple setup while providing a huge gear range completely enclosed inside the rear wheel. Free of complicated and delicate external parts, they are resilient and practically maintenance free. No dropped chains. No crossed gears. No more derailleur adjustment.
A single bar mounted shifter simplifies the process
Internal Cable Routing
We've routed the cables for the shifter and the rear brake inside the tubing of the bike, creating a clean and elegant appearance. Just another way we've seamlessly married the form and function of this bicycle design.
Brake and shifter cables entering the frame
Materials
We build this bike out of 4130 chromoly steel for its high strength, low weight and durability. Steel is the most resilient choice for city bikes as it takes the daily abuse of riding better than any other frame material. Meanwhile, at 24 pounds, it's light enough to hoist up a few flights of stairs.
Strong and lightweight steel
Design and Build
Using the Sutro as the canvas, each bicycle is custom designed by each rider, anywhere in the world, and built one at a time by Mission Bicycle Company. The experienced staff and curated components will help you turn this innovative frame into a bike specific to your needs. No experience necessary.
Choose from hundreds of frame colors
Our Story
Eman Eng: I’ve put the torch to dozens of different frame designs and I’ve ridden each one through the streets of San Francisco in pursuit of the perfect city bike. Each success was assimilated into the next design and after many years and many miles the Sutro was born.
Mission Bicycle Company: We began with a simple premise, give people the bicycle they want and they'll ride. Each bike is custom designed by each rider and then hand built right here in San Francisco.
Next Steps
With your support we are going to release the Sutro out into the world. If we meet our goal the frame will go into production and all backers will receive their rewards. If we don’t hit our funding target, no money changes hands. To reach our goal we are giving you the opportunity to be among the first riders of the Sutro and to do so with great incentives.
Complete Bicycle Backers Please Note: The complete bicycle reward at $1,234 includes customization of standard components and colors. Further customization and upgrades are welcomed and available, but not included.

Keep an eye out as the last T-shirts and posters should be arriving to you in the next week or two.
In addition we are only a few bikes away from delivering all Sutros.  It's been an incredibly hectic time but also a lot of fun.  Thanks for your enthusiasm and all the stories you've shared with us as we've designed and built these bikes.

campaign.story:
Wow!  We made it, thanks to YOU!  So here's the deal.  What if we make $15K?  With a day and a half left?  Why not?  Overall we are planning a whole season of fundraisers to help support various aspects of our project.  Lighting our project alone will cost $10K.  Raising a bit more now will help us ease the burden later.  Please tell your friends about our project and let's keep it rolling and see what we can do together!  
Other ways to support the project include donating bikes and especially bike wheels, if you are in Seattle or Portland.  Help Johnny and the tail team make their magic!  Or if you have welding or sewing skills, get the fun of throwing down with our team for a day or two.  Thank you so much for making Quetzalita a SUCCESS!
The Firebulb team brings Apocalypta Quetzalita, great-granddaughter of the Mexican feathered serpent god Quetzalcoatl, to Burning Man this year. Standing 46 feet tall above the playa, the sumptuous, voluptuous goddess created by our team will embody the act of shedding our heavy past, as she sheds the skin of Quetzalcoatl from whose mouth she is born.  She will reveal her readiness for the challenges of the era before us by deploying magnificent wings that spring from her back once the skin is shed.  Her 55' long mobile tail made from repurposed bicycle frames and wheels will draw patterns on the Playa canvas as it is pushed by participants, revealing how the acts we create today form the inertia of the future: we choose to create the culture we want to live in.
Made from steel with elements in copper, chrome, stainless and re-purposed waste, Quetzalita glimmers in the sunlight and under lighting at night.  With a frame of rigid steel holding her long curving neck, Quetzalita's body is wrought from stainless braided wire, copper and mild steel elements--a design based on filigree jewelry, on a massive scale.  Her markings follow the natural patterns of a Karman Street Vortex, the pattern of liquids encountering resistance.  

At night spectacular animated lighting reveals Quetzalita's mood.  With spotlights coloring her from the outside at times, and animated stripes and spots illuminating her from the inside at others, participants will witness her going back and forth from spirit form to embodied being.  Occasional bursts of flame emanate from her mouth and spiral hummingbird tongue, lighting up the playa with heat and bursts of sound.

During the beginning half of the week Quetzalita is being born from the mouth of her great grandfather--Quetzalcoatl, the Aztec feathered serpent God of fertility and war.  The skin of Quetzalcoatl is made from large copper feathers and square spirals made of copper, steel, chrome, and metallic fabrics with industrial detritus--car parts, computer chips, gleaming machinery and other modern artifacts, all attached flexibly to each other on an underlying canvas skin.  The skin sparkles in the sunlight, at once seductive, but also embued with the power of all that we are shedding as we lift the veil our old ways and replace them with the new ways of being we are striving to embody.  In a ritual on Wednesday of the burn week, participants help Quetzalita shed her great-grandfather's skin and sprout wings from her back, which emerge through the use of pulleys from a tube inside her body and drop down in a fan to be secured to her back with guy wires.  The ritual is accompanied by the burning of Copal (to add a scent aspect to the sculpture) and the sharing of chocolate with participants in the ritual.  As the skin is removed, we see a narrow slit that allows participants to enter her cozy, fabric-lined womb that rests below her neck and before the flexible part of her tail.  After being shed, the skin remains with the piece, anchored on a PVC framework, a testament to our past, emerging from a masculine-dominated era into a feminine one.
Et en français maintenant...
En 2012, les temps changent. les aztecs nous parlent de transformations majeures, de "fin". 
Mais est ce que "la fin" ne laisse pas la place au "début"? 
Cette année, le thème de Burning Man est : "fertilité 2.0". 
En octobre 2011, quatre femmes se retrouvent  autour d un désir commun: Capra , LaTisha, Peggy et Elodie discutent. l une d elle propose " Quetzal Coatl" comme thème de travail, le dieu serpent a plume des aztecs, 
Le thème du dieu serpent a plume a beaucoup voyager entre les différentes cultures sud américaines de l époques, les premières représentations remontent aux alentour de 900 ans avant jésus christ, et l on continue de pouvoir suivre son évolution a travers les siècles jusque a la conquête espagnole. Dans toutes les cultures qu il traverse, QuetzalCoatl est le dieu de la fertilité, de la guerre, de la culture, de la société des hommes, Venus est son etoile. et les prêtres interprètent ses dires. Il est le lien entre le ciel et la terre.
Apres de nombreuses rencontres, discussions autour de ce thème, et embarassees a l idée de recréer le dieu serpent des  aztecs, 1500 ans plus tard! Elles décident de travailler autour de l idée de l arrière petite fille du dieu serpent, et elles créent: "Apocalipta Quetzalita". 
Selon La définition originale du mot "Apocalypse":
(Greek: ἀποκάλυψις apokálypsis; "lifting of the veil" or "revelation") is a disclosure of something hidden from the majority of mankind in an era dominated by falsehood and misconception, i.e. the veil to be lifted. The Apocalypse of John (Greek Ἀποκάλυψις Ἰωάννου) is the Book of Revelation, the last book of the New Testament. By extension, apocalypse can refer to any End Time scenario, or to the end of the world in general. 
ce qui siginfie (pour ceux dont l anglais n est pas assez courant), du grec, "lever du voile", ou "révélation", révéler quelque chose de cachée a la majorité de l humanité, dans une ere dominée par la menterie, les idées fausses, le voile se leve. L apocalypse celons St Jean est le Livre des Revelations, le dernier livre du nouveau testament. Par extension,apocalypse peut se référer a n importe quel scénario de fin du monde, ou de la fin d'un monde en général.
Aujourd hui, Quetzalita, Deesse serpente ailée de 14 metres de hauts, 18 metres de longs, se développent dans nos imaginations. 
Pendants la première moitié de la semaine du festival de Burning Man, notre déesse porte la peaux de son arrière grand père, le mercredi soir,  nuit de pleine lune, l equipe de firebulb, lors d une cérémonie, aide Quetzalita a se debarasser de cette vieille et glorieuse peau, et a dévoiler enfin ce qu elle est, de grande aile jusque ici cachees pourront enfin se déployer, et finalement libérée, quetzalita nous enchantera de son feu sacre, ses ecailles de metales brillants de milles feus, son ventre enfin ouvert a ses disciples.
Pour cette nouvelle ere de l humanité, il est temp de changer nos systèmes, on sait maintenant que nous touchons a la fin de nos systèmes sociaux/politiques/economiques, surranes, surdates, ils ne nous servent plus, ils nous desservent, nous ne sommes plus maitres de nos systèmes, mais esclaves. je ne vous apprend rien! 
Aujourd hui il est temps d abandonner, de lâcher prise nos anciens modeles. a nous de décider de ce qui est bon, juste et riche, de ce que nous voulons emporter avec nous dans le futur et préparer pour les générations a venir. Laisser tomber les anciennes structures, croyances, systèmes qui ne nous servent plus.
Notre belle déesse Serpente, a travers sa propre transformation nous inspire a en faire de meme, abandonner nos mechanismes démodes, nos petites manies, nos limitations. Elle nous invite a nous réinventer, a nous surpasser, a être le meilleur de nous meme.
Cette sculpture géante, faites de métal, pourrat être escaladée de l intérieur, un nid de velours pourpre au coeur de son ventre nous acceuille, sa queue faite de vélos recycles est mobile, les gens sont invites a changer sa position autant qu ils le souhaitent.
Le soir, alors que la nuit tombe, les ecailles de metals, illuminées de milles couleurs, nous indiquent son humeur…attention lorsqu' elle devient orange et rouge elle se prépare a cracher son feu!
Nous avons besoin de votre soutien pour réaliser cette oeuvre, nous somme en pre-sélection pour recevoir une bourse de la fondation pour l art de Burning Man. Les euros sont acceptes! C est de l'art véritablement publique, fonde par les gens pour les gens. Nous espérons, une fois le festival termine, pouvoir installer cette pièce dans un lieu publique ou les gens pourront venir l admirer et en être inspirer.
Partager ce lien avec le plus grand nombre de gens possible, et nous esperons vous faire rêver a un monde nouveau.
Merci.
L'equipe de Firebulb

campaign.creator_bio:
Firebulb
3 created · 13 backed
Firebulb makes inspiring large scale art using flame as one material. The project of multi-disciplinary artist/performer Capra J'neva...See more

updates.update_content:
Hi Great Backers!  The Firebulb team wants to thank you again for your massive showing of support.  Here's what happened:
On Monday, after we canceled the Kickstarter, we got a message from Bettie June (head of the artery) to call her.  She said they were just finalizing the budget and if they got extra money in their budget this year, things were looking good for our project and if not they weren't.  By way of explanation, we asked the burning man org for a large amount of funding for this project, a fair amount higher than their typical top grants--partially this is necessary as it is much more difficult to raise funds for big projects in the Northwest than the Bay Area, LA or NY.  This is because additional art granting organizations have less money for grants, and because lower incomes in our area make it more difficult to do private fundraising.  Because of this, the success of our Kickstarter was a huge boost to our project!  She was disappointed to hear that we had cancelled the Kickstarter, but we told her we felt confident we could raise the money again if needed.

Hello dear backers!  From the depths of our hearts, our whole team is truly blown away by all of you coming together to support our project.  We are really excited about making her come to life!
As you may have gleaned from some of our previous postings, our project is reliant on several sources of funding.  We have been hoping that one of those sources would be an honorarium grant from the Burning Man organization, and we timed our Kickstarter fundraiser to end well after (we thought) the time when we would hear from the committee what the results of the grant process were going to be.  Unfortunately, this year, the grant committee, overwhelmed with the ticket sales adventure and with an unprecedented 359 art grant applications (!) are running about ten days later than we thought.

oh Gracious Goddess!!! we made it! i just saw that we passed the $10,000 mark! this is so exciting, i can't believe it!!
THANKYOUTHANKYOUTHANKYOU!! this is marvelously awesome!!!
now lets see how far we can get in 40 hours, can you please share this beautiful success with your network? invite them to support us in this incredible adventure?!

updates.update_userinfo: et en français dans le texte! french text!
updates.update_content:
Et voila chers amis, je viens de poster la version en français de notre belle histoire! juste en dessous du texte sur la première page!
Gardons maintenant les doigts croises pour que l'on obtienne la bourse du BORG, la fondation pour l art de Burning Man!
Merci encore a tous nos supporteurs pour leur généreuses contributions!

One of our lighting team experts (these guys are so good they blow our minds!) has this brilliantly programmed algorithmic controller up his sleeve, which is probably going to be the effect we will use to make Quetzalita's scales shimmer from behind the filigree.  Imagine this with thousands of LEDs.  We will tune the colors and a wash of color and EL wire animation will coordinate with the explosion from her tongue and fangs!
Jesse Banks worked really hard to create this, and we are super blessed to have him on our team.

As with all things Burning Man this year, we at Firebulb are awaiting some big news from the Burning Man organization (affectionately referred to as the BORG).  At the end of last week we got the first glimmer of what may come: we are in the running to receive an art grant!  
This is huge.  A project like this is expensive and cannot be accomplished without major funding, and it looks like we might actually get a large chunk of that funding from Burning Man itself.  We are still waiting, and waiting... and waiting (oh the waiting is killing me!) but we hope to have a final answer, "soon."

Hi everyone!  Core team member Peggy here... 
First, I have to say, Wow!  After Capra's update on Friday, you guys really stepped up: we crossed $3,000 in a matter of hours, and by Monday we had topped $4,000 - amazing!  Thank you!!
Meanwhile the crew has been hard at work on prototyping different aspects of the sculpture.  I'm the team lead on designing and building Quetzalita's beautiful filigree exoskeleton, so my task this weekend was to make a sample of this and test out the materials and my ideas.  Check out my photos and video below!

project_data.project_name: Apocalypta Quetzalita: A Burning Man Installation (Canceled)

campaign.story:
This Kickstarter page is only possible thanks to the extraordinary support and encouragement of the r/atheism folk on reddit.com. A few weeks ago I posted some pictures of my "Atheist Shoes" there and I was blown away by how many sweet and encouraging messages I received, urging me to make more shoes. Actually, it was a bit scary... but in a good way... and, 6 weeks later, I've figured out how I'll be able to make shoes for you all. This page is the first step towards realising that dream and I hope some of you will be willing to pre-order your shoes, so that I have the upfront capital I need to get busy!
Thanks guys. And I hope you will soon be able to enjoy your shoes.
Now, I realise that some of you haven't the foggiest what an Atheist shoe is. And, admittedly, an atheist shoe sounds like a peculiar idea. But we think a shoe is a lovely, understated way for atheists to out themselves and to be less shy about their godlessness. And we also think our Bauhaus-inspired, 1930s-infatuated shoes will be a welcome antidote to the samey junk pumped out by the big sneaker corporations - not only do we feel our designs are prettier, but we know that the care, craftsmanship and quality of materials going into our shoes are superior to those invested by N**e, *onver*e and Ad***s.
So how do you get your shoes? It's easy. You can buy your shoes, here, today, by making a pledge. You'll see amongst our rewards that you can pre-order a pair of shoes for $180, which includes shipping. And then, a month from now, you'll be able to log into our website and choose the colour and sole you'd like us to send you. Those who pre-order their shoes on Kickstarter will be the first to get them!
In the mean time, we'll have invested your dosh in producing your shoes and we're hopeful they'll be ready to ship by May 1st, if not sooner. 
We're not yet ready to show you all the available colours and soles, but we're working on it and it would really help us if, when you make your pledge, you could give us a hint as to which colour you'd like and which sole. We can't guarantee your choice will be available in the end, but if enough people want something, then we'll definitely be able to make it!
Please tell us which of the following colours appeals to you most: cream, charcoal black, chocolate brown, brown & sand combo, petrol blue, British racing car green, grey. And which of these soles: "Ich Bin Atheist" (embossed), "Darwin Loves" (embossed), "Atheist, Jawohl" (embossed), "Ich Bin Atheist" (decorative).
We're really happy to have your support. And we promise we will continue to update you in the days ahead with more pictures and news as we finalise our production plans and get ready to launch our godless wares to the world.
Any questions, please write to david@atheistberlin.com.
Thanks so much!
David
PS - I know I'm wearing odd shoes in the video, but don't worry... the shoes we send you will be matching in colour!
">
" />

If you haven't see it yet, our new webshop is now open for business! www.atheistberlin.com
A million thanks, once again, to all our Kickstarter Backers. None of it possible without those brave, gambling few :)
David

Dear Kickstarter Pledgers,
Those of you who pledged $180 or $250 should have received from us by now a message with a coupon code, directing you to our website where you can, at long last, order your shoes!
About half of you have done so already, so it seems to be working ok... just a few minor glitches so far .)
However, a few of the messages we sent bounced back. We'll try emailing you again but, if you haven't heard from us, please get in touch with us here or at david@atheistberlin.com.

Dear Backers,
Let me thank you once again for your patience in waiting for your atheist shoes to arrive! We're very sorry that it's taking a little longer than expected... several small obstacles have mounted to put us about 4 weeks behind our initial estimates... though the more we learn about the complexities of producing shoes on such a large scale, the more grateful we are that we're ONLY 4 weeks behind! Still, we appreciate you've been waiting and that sucks... so thank you again for being so cool and supportive about that.

updates.update_userinfo: YOU CAN STILL ORDER ATHEIST SHOES!!
updates.update_content:
June 2012
UPDATE - visit www.atheistberlin.com to order our shoes.
May 2012
Our website will be up and running the day after we receive delivery of our first batch of shoes, probably about 4 weeks from now. And you'll be able to place an order there and then... with the shoes priced around the same as they have been on Kickstarter.

updates.update_userinfo: A FINAL WHOPPING GREAT BIG THANK YOU!
updates.update_content:
Happy Easter Everyone! 
With just 3 hours left to pledge, before Atheist Shoes become officially 'funded', I just wanted to say once again how very grateful we are for your support. What started as a peculiar idea that made us smile has, in the last 4 weeks, become a very real and tangible project that is going to beautify 600 feet and, hopefully, create some ripples of enjoyment wherever those feet tread. It's quite an amazing thing... we're still pretty stunned that we now have a small shoe business on our hands... and we owe it all to your pledges. So thank you, THANK YOU, for altering the lives of a handful of atheists in Berlin and for giving them the opportunity to do something fun and interesting that they really think worthwhile. After this first batch of shoes is made, who knows what the future will hold... but we have decided we're going to make more shoes and that we're going to try our very best to make Atheist Shoes a sustainable enterprise. This Kickstarter page is hopefully just a beginning... but we'll let your feet decide what kind of future we have .)

And, on the 7th day, he thought about having a rest but then he saw that there were still pledges coming in and and 3 weeks to go and he thought 'cripes, how many shoes are we gonna have to make here?' and he put some Of Montreal on and got back to work.

campaign.story:
2010 was a year of record deaths for illegal migrants entering the
U.S. via Arizona’s Sonoran Desert — 230 in all.

It’s impossible to know how many migrants survive the days-long
journey, led by high-priced guides, with temperatures soaring up to 130 degrees in the summer months.  But every year since 2001 no less than 150 mummified and decomposed bodies have been discovered in remote areas of the desert, eventually taken to the Pima County Forensic Science Center in Tucson, AZ which faces the herculean task of analyzing and storing their remains, archiving their possessions — and hopefully — determining their identities.

In the fall of 2011, I traveled to Pima County, where I spent a week photographing the day-to-day operations of the facility, documenting the receiving area, autopsy room, and archive of border crossers’ personal effects. 
Working in the Medical Examiner's Office
Gurneys in Receiving Room
I also traveled to Green Valley, AZ, photographing belongings left on the desert floor by migrants awaiting road-side pick-up in the dead of night.
The U.S. Border Patrol monitoring the wall in Nogales, Arizona
Why This Book is Important
This book is important for a number of reasons.  It is a way of humanizing the immigration issue we face in our country.  It points to how desperate the individuals are to escape whatever their circumstances were and start a new life.  Essentially this books stands as a kind of memorial to people who died alone, without ceremony and who often are still unknown.
Personal Effects of John Doe ML#: 11-01245
The BookWith your help, the first edition will include 1,500 9x12 casebound copies of 112 pages with 65 four-color plates in the fall of 2012.

How It WorksIf you decide to make a pledge, your credit card will be charged when my project reaches its funding deadline date on March 10, 2012, but only if my project is fully funded.  It's an all or nothing situation -- if my project is not fully funded, your credit card is not charged, and I do not receive any donations.

To pledge to my project, click the green “Back This Project” button on the upper right side of the page. You will be asked to enter your pledge amount. From there, you will go through the Amazon checkout process. Note that you must finish the Amazon checkout process for your pledge to be recorded.  Kickstarter only supports credit card payments through Amazon Payments.  No cash or checks.  I expect to ship rewards in the Fall of 2012.  

Rewards
Please see the schedule of rewards to the right that correspond with the images below.
Selected Signed Print Images
Sleeves of Personal Effects
X-Ray in Use
Vultures in Green Valley
Now It Is Up To You
The more people I reach, the better chance I have of being funded.  So please help me spread the word.
Thank you for considering my project.

campaign.story:
10 March 2012: Check out the new rewards! See our latest update for details.
Occuprint is a volunteer-run collaborative project that curates, collects, prints and distributes posters and graphics produced by and for the global Occupy movement. In the Fall, Occuprint launched with an all-poster newspaper, published in collaboration with the Occupied Wall Street Journal.  Since then, we’ve been sending the paper across the globe as a freely distributed tool to keep the #occupy movement as visible as possible, as beautiful as possible, and in as many places as possible.
The response has been overwhelming. Since the newspaper was released, we’ve received hundreds of poster submissions from all over the world—many of which we’ve archived on our website: 
occuprint.org
Now, we want to start getting these images out beyond the internet: into the streets and into the homes, offices, and schools of #occupy supporters worldwide.
We’re raising money for two reasons:
1. So we can print posters—tens of thousands of posters—and start distributing them anywhere there are #occupy supporters.
2. So we can print a limited edition portfolio of screen printed images, which will ultimately live in the permanent collections of museums, libraries, and other arts institutions.
The Posters
(These are the first two posters we're printing - this week! (March 13th) - with the funds raised by kickstarter. The first is by Molly Crabapple, the second is by Josh MacPhee. We've been so successful that we're able to print 5000 of each! - we added both of them to new rewards for those interested.)
(This is the first poster we've massed produced - by Alexandra Clotfelter - and we're offering it as one of our rewards.  The images we print in 2012 will be just as amazing!)
While we screen print ourselves, for larger runs of posters we work with union print shops—one here in Queens, NY and another in Detroit, MI. We have budgeted into this proposal:
$1,800: Two thousand (2,000) copies of a 24” x 36” poster (this includes printing and an estimate of our distribution costs—postage and packaging).
$6,000: Twenty thousand (20,000) copies of a broadsheet:, poster on one side, short articles and other information on the back (again, includes printing and distribution costs).
$2,000: Three thousand (3,000) copies of an 18” x 24” poster, with articles printed on the back.
$2,000: Three thousand (3,000) copies of a second 18” x 24” poster, with articles printed on the back.
TOTAL: $11,800
The specifics of what we print might vary slightly. If we receive more money, either our print runs will increase or we will print additional materials. Occuprint is a volunteer, activist project—all of the money we raise goes directly to printing and shipping.
The Portfolio
The Occuprint portfolio will consist of thirty poster images from our website. We’ve had help choosing the images from members of Occupy the Hood, Occupy Together, and the Occupied Wall Street Journal. We are working with a number of different printers to make this happen, from members of the OWS Screenprinting Guild to a Do- It-Yourself printshop in Nashville.
We will produce an edition of 100 portfolios, and that’s it. That means these are going to be super rare. — 35 are reserved for artists and printers, 30 more are being offered to libraries and educational institutions across the country, and then Occuprint will keep 10 portfolios to lend out for events and exhibitions. That leaves 25 portfolios, which we are offering to YOU, our Kickstarter supporters, to help us make all of this possible.
All of the prints in the portfolio are numbered and initialed by the printer, then stamped with the Occuprint seal. There is a front sheet, the “calaphon,” which offers a short explanation of the project, and lists all the artists and printers as well as the major donors (over 1000$). Finally, all the prints are packaged together into a presentation folio, printed with Occuprint’s seal.
Here's a selection of images that will be included:
The costs for printing this portfolio include paper, ink, shop fees, the presentation folio, and compensating the printers for their work.
They are estimated as follows:
$3,000: Paper (including the portfolio itself)
$2,000: Shop fees and printing supplies
$8,000: Printing Labor
$2,000: Shipping
[Sub-total: $15,000, minus income from institutional sales : $10,000]
TOTAL needed from Kickstarter for portfolios: $5,000
TOTAL NEEDED FOR BOTH PROJECTS = $16,800
# # # # #  # #  PROJECT FAQ # # # # # # # #
We've had a couple people ask about the rewards that involve portfolio prints.  It says "our choice" which has made people worry that we might choose prints they don't want - which is a fair concern.  Here is what we will do: after the kickstarter is over, we will email all the people who chose rewards that involve portfolio prints, asking them to list their top 5 choices (top 10 if your reward is for 5 prints). Once we have all these responses, we will go through and make sure everyone gets their first or second choice (hopefully everyone gets their first choice - it just depends on how diverse your tastes are!).  The process will work like this:
top available choice for each reward, 
then 5 print rewards get their second available print choice
then each reward gets their next available print choice (reverse order as round 1)
then the 5 print rewards get their 4th and 5th available choices
When we curated the portfolio we had such a wide range of interest in different prints, that I'm really not worried about people getting the prints they want. I suppose you can't be certain, but hopefully you all at least know the process now!

updates.update_content:
Well first of all - may day was a lot of fun. We spent most of April frantically trying to get materials out accross the country and throughout NYC, and on May Day we got to just enjoy the crowds.  Occuprint had a nice workshop as part of the Free University in Madison Square Park, and then the following week, we also led another workshop/discussion at the CUNY Graduate Center's James Gallery - part of the CUNY GC GA's Transforming Assemblies project.
Now - we're going to spend the next two weeks getting all our kickstarter rewards mailed and out portfolio finished. Tomorrow is our first big work day - so hopefully most if not all of our packages will go out then. (we already ordered 8 huge boxes of shipping supplies - they're waiting for us at interference archive!)

Hi Kickstarter Friends!!!  Sorry we're not sending more updates...  but here's a little news:
We've printed a ton of May Day materials -- thanks to all your support - and are now in the process of distributing them. We've done three rounds of shipments to cities across the country - ($1500 worth!!!) - big boxes of Strike! tabloids and tubes filled with posters and stickers.  We gave out a lot of materials at the Spring Awakening event in Central Park last weekend, and this week we've been getting lots of drop-ins at the interference archive, where everything is stored. People are really getting these things out into the world - its really exciting!
We're just about out of the first general strike posters - the Molly Crabapple and Josh Macphee images, and we've got a couple thousand of the third and fourth posters left - though we shouldn't have much trouble getting rid of them all before May 1 (except the ones we're saving for our donors of course!). Tomorrow we get our last May day/first summer poster back from the printer - image is attached below - it was created by an artist in Portland, Nina Montenegro - and we printed it extra large: 24 x 36. Basically, everyone who selected the "one of everything" rewards is going to be making out really really well....

Hi backers!!  We haven't forgotten about you - just been hard at work getting ready for May Day -- we hope to get our broadsheet off to the printer this weekend, and then another set of two posters shortly thereafter.  The broadsheet will have 4 posters and then a collection of texts about strikes that we've been putting together on the backs of the posters.  We've also got 50,000 stickers en route - they should arrive early next week - so if all goes according to plan we'll be shipping boxes of all this material to activists around the country in under a week!

Things are heating up at Occuprint -- you saw the first two May Day posters that we printed in the last updates - 8,000 posters are already distributed and out into the world: Detroit, Chicago, New Haven, Boston...  and Union Square! Things are heating up again in NY, and we're ready to be part of the party. 
We've initiated a collaborative design process (so far about 15 people have plugged in) at the Interference Archive, and some exciting things are brewing - we've got designs in the works for matchbooks (general strike - how could we resist?), stickers, coasters, and of course posters, lots of posters.  As you see - we want to do a lot more than the 4 publications listed in our initial project description -- and so long as we raise a little bit more money, we should be able to.

This is the last week of Occuprint's campaign to raise funds to print tens of thousands of posters for the Occupy movement. We hit 100% of our funding target more than a week ago, but with more pledges we'll be able to do even more, so encourage your friends to chip in!
Share the Occuprint Kickstarter campaign: Facebook · Twitter · Reddit
This weekend we distributed seven thousand posters at the annual Left Forum in New York City! Many out-of-town attendees are heading back home—to Riverside, Wilmington, Boston, Baltimore, Toronto and many, many more towns—bearing thousands of posters to spread the message of the far and wide.

Things are in a flurry of activity here at Occuprint HQ, so we thought it's time for another update. Thanks to your wonderful support, we feel confident enough on the fundraising side of things that we've begun work on some new printing projects. We have almost reached our funding goal with more than two weeks to go still, but we can still use your help! Spread the word about this campaign to fellow activists and friends around the world.
Share the Occuprint Kickstarter campaign: Facebook · Twitter · Reddit
General Strike Posters & New Rewards

First, a big thank you to all our backers! With three weeks left to go in our Kickstarter campaign, we are excited that you have contributed almost $10,000 to help us print thousands of posters for the Occupy movement. You are making it possible for the movement's visual culture to keep proliferating as we enter the American Spring. Please continue to tell your friends about our campaign so we can reach our fundraising goal soon. 
Share the Occuprint Kickstarter campaign: Facebook · Twitter · Reddit
Portfolio Sales

campaign.story:
LINX were created because I wanted a construction game that was cheap, flexible and light. With LINX you can build everything from ambitious room-sized structures to intricate table-top sculptures, all using LINX connectors and standard drinking straws. LINX are portable, less expensive than anything else around, and ultra light weight, so that even if your mammoth construction falls, no one gets hurt. Here are a few more reasons why LINX are awesome:
• Modular and Flat. The connectors come in flat grids which easily snap apart, intersect, and lock into place to create a three dimensional star shape to allow for more complex structures. 
• Standard Straws. The connectors are designed to accommodate most standard straws that can be found in your local grocery, drug, or big-box store.
• Limitless Building. By cutting, bending, or using multiple colors of straws, the possibilities are endless. You can make highly organized geometric structures, or free-form tangles. 
• Educational. Beyond being a fun way to spend an afternoon, LINX inspire creativity and give children an opportunity to develop their motor and spatial skills through hands-on play. If the campaign is successful, one of our first goals will be to get LINX in the hands of teachers and physical therapists. 
• Sustainable. We are striving to make LINX as sustainable as possible. The connectors will be made out of a kid-friendly recycled or bio plastic in the US, and come in the most minimal of packaging. Additionally, LINX are designed to be manufactured with little or no waste, and we’ll be involved in every step of the process to ensure socially responsible practices. 
Sounds great right? But without your help LINX won’t get off the ground. The LINX prototypes are complete, the materials and manufacturing research has been done, now all we need is your support to get the first production run going. The LINX connectors need to be injection molded, which has a very high setup cost. Your pledge will go toward creating the needed injection mold, developing packaging, and meeting our first minimum order quantity at the factory.
Please consider helping kickstart LINX by pledging at the $25 level and receive 5 LINX grids, thats 180 pieces, enough to make all of the constructions in the video and images below.

updates.update_content:
Dear Backers, 
I hope you are well. 
Here are some news about JIX:
1/JIX wins the Chicago Athenaeum's "GOOD DESIGN Award 2014".
https://chi-athenaeum.org/children-products-2014/
The U.S. GOOD DESIGN Awards is a design awards program organized annually by The Chicago Athenaeum Museum of Architecture and Design (Illinois) in cooperation with the European Center for Architecture, Art, Design and Urban Studies.

Dear Backers,
  I hope this finds you well. It 's been a long time since you've participated in the success of this project, and I wanted to give you an update.  
First of all,  I want to make sure that we keep in touch and that you are able to find me, so you should know that, although the product is the same, the brand name has changed and is now called JIX. The website dedicated to JIX is www.jix.us.com and you can follow us on facebook, pinterest, facebook, twitter, instagram @jixproject.

Dear Everyone, 
I hope you are well.
I just wanted to let you know that I will be presenting a new gigantic sculpture made of LINX connectors and straws on the occasion of the Montreal/Brooklyn exhibition at Parker's Box gallery. 
http://www.brooklynmontreal.com/en/programming/parkers-box

Dear Backers, 
Happy new year to you! I hope you all got your linx by now and that you had fun playing with them. 
Thank you for your nice comments and emails of support!
LINX is now ready to be marketed.

Dear Backers
I hope this finds you well. Some of you were asking me what was happening with the project so, here is a little update.
We are currently trying different materials, in terms of resistance, rigidity, opacity, durability… This part of the process is very delicate and takes time. So far, we are not 100% satisfied with the material but we are heading in the right direction. We are expecting a new set of samples in the next few days. Once we are good, we can finish the packaging and start the production.
As you know, the estimated delivery date is november 2012 and we are definitely on schedule. Now, we are doing our best to be able to send you Linx sooner than expected.
What really matters though, is to make Linx right, which is why we are paying so much attention to every detail of the production process.
Thank you for your patience,

If you tried to sign up on the link that I sent you yesterday,
www.linxtoy.com
 you probably noticed that there was a mistake that has now been corrected. Everything is back to normal.
Sorry for the inconvenience,

campaign.story:
Instaprint is a location based photo booth that can transform parties and events by putting a camera in everyone's hand. By setting Instaprint to look out for specific locations or hashtags, any Instagram tagged appropriately will automatically be printed out on inkless paper. Get one for your next party, event, wedding, fiesta....
THE BACKSTORY
Instaprint was invented in the spring of 2011 by our small company called BREAKFAST. Over the past year our prototype devices have been seen at events such as store openings, product launches, a variety of different parties and events including The Grammys and Lady Gaga concerts.
Going from prototype to consumer product is a massive step, and is something BREAKFAST has been working on for almost a year. It's a huge endeavor that will require us to bring on more staff and dedicate many months to make it all happen. Some things are sure to change as we get into the thick of it, but that means things will only get better.
We're really psyched to try and make this happen, and we hope you'll help us reach our goal. We can't thank all of you enough for any support you can give!
WHERE DOES THE CASH GO?
$175,000 will go towards the many months of mechanical design, digital design, hardware development, software development, prototyping and testing for the device hardware, software and website.
$260,000 will go towards the parts, molds, inkless paper, fabrication and build of the devices.
$20,000 for packaging and shipping all of the rewards.
$45,000 goes to KickStarter and Amazon's fees.
INKLESS TECHNOLOGY
Rather than dealing with ink cartridges that constantly need replacement, Instaprint uses an inkless technology where all color is pulled right from the paper itself. 
DAISY CHAINING
For higher volume printing and an even better look, additional Instaprints can be daisy chained together to share power and connectivity. Each multi-box set up requires one Instaprint that has a controller and Wi-Fi module which then drives the other controller-less Instaprints.
QUICK & EASY WI-FI SETUP
When Instaprint is powered up for the first time, it will show up as a Wi-fi network on your phone or computer. Once connected to the device, you'll be able to set the Wi-Fi network it will use to connect to the internet and associate your Instaprint device(s) with your instaprint.me account.
INSTAPRINT.ME
Instaprint.me will be your one-stop-shop for setting up your Instaprint devices with locations and hashtags for different events, and will also host your event galleries. These galleries showcase all the Instagrams printed at each of your events, and give attendees a place online to view the collection of prints.
TECH SPECS
Size and weight
Height:        6.5 inches (165.1 mm)
Width:         6.5 inches (165.1 mm)
Depth:         2.5 inches (63.5 mm)
Weight:        1.5 lbs. (.68 kg)
Paper size:  2 inches x 3 inches

Paper capacity
Our proposed design has the potential to hold  50+ sheets per refill, but until we enter production we’re unable to commit to an exact number. It is possible that number could rise or drop, but we’re determined to push for the highest capacity possible.

Power
High performance coiled cables provide DC current to each Instaprint.
Power supplies will vary depending upon number of Instaprints in the kit you order. A larger power supply may be required for each additional Instaprint that is added to a daisy chain.
Power supplies will work on 120v as well as 220v, but may require an adapter for international sockets.
Printer engine & paper type/price
We are still assessing several different printer engine options to ensure the highest quality, performance, and reliability.
The paper type will vary with the engine we decide on. Paper will be readily accessible either directly from us or from places such as amazon.com, and should cost around $12 for 30 sheets.
Setup & operational requirements
Internet connected device (computer, smart phone, tablet) running a modern web browser
Wi-Fi network connected to the internet
Instaprint.me account (free)
People using the Instagram app, with photos set to public
In the box
Instaprint 
High performance coiled power cable
Power supply with US plug
Starter Paper

updates.update_content:
When we first considered mass producing Instaprint we weren’t quite sure of what the demand would truly be, or if the price as it stands today would be too much for people to swallow. Kickstarter provided a place where we could safely test the waters, and for that we are incredibly happy for everything we have learned from this experience... that the demand is in fact there, but that price point currently isn’t where it needs to be for this to really take off. 
As of today, we’re not sure how possible it will be to bring that down, and so we’ll have to wait and see if we’re able to come back in the future with a newer, cheaper approach. In the meantime, we will be shifting effort and resources towards the rental of Instaprint for larger events. While we know that isn’t ideal for many of our backers, it’s a way to keep Instaprint out in the world while we devise next steps.  If any of you are ever interested in renting a set up - you can learn more here: .

First off, let us apologize for not giving any updates sooner. The culprit has been the absolutely overwhelming amount of people and companies who have been reaching out in the thousands from all over the globe. The reach that this project has gained is monumental, and has been covered by Time, Fast Company, BBC, Mashable, Engadget and so many many more. We are truly humbled and appreciative of everyone’s support and we’re trying our best to keep up with onslaught.
Onto the updates....

We'll be running all around South by Southwest this week, and we'll have several Instaprint prototypes in tow. We'll be tweeting out where we'll be from @breakfastny if you want to meet up and check them out. See you down there!
